Grant instead of using Alka-Seltzer and water you get the same reaction if you pour in vinegar and baking soda

The only new thing about this to me is using the Alka-Seltzer.  We used to do this back in ''84  through' '86 with baking soda, vinegar, and Centrum child-proof pull cap vitamin bottles for 4th of July "fireworks". At the time we were living somewhere where you couldn't buy fireworks, which was a huge let down after having lived in a different state and being able to light 'em off (man, what I wouldn't have given during those years for some flying saucers and some parachute mortars, those had been my favorites in '82 and '83). Sure there was going to a park or somewhere and seeing the professional displays, which we did even when we could light 'em off at home. But it was always so fun to have the sparklers and have dad light off a few fireworks. Since we could light them off at home, dad did the old baking soda and vinegar bit, but he used a used Centrum bottle because at the time the pull tab child proof caps just popped off (haven't had Centrum vitamins in years so I don't know what the caps are like now) with a, well, pop when you went to get the vitamins. So they made nice pressure chambers until the pressure blew the cap up into the air. No comparsion for being able to light off actual roman candles and firecrackers, but for not having them they made for some fun and safer "fireworks"
